questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

 

The patient exhibits symptoms including erythematous lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin, arthralgia, and breathlessness, which are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The rash described is typical of an SLE rash and not dermatomyositis, which presents with rashes over the knuckles known as Gottron's papules.

 

For diagnosing SLE, anti-dsDNA antibodies are very useful due to their high specificity. Although their sensitivity is relatively low (30-50%), the specificity is very high (>90-95%), making them reliable markers for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are also associated with disease activity in SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: These are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, not classic SLE.

 

Option C. Anticentromere antibodies: These are typically seen in limited forms of scleroderma, particularly CREST syndrome, and are not associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA is a good initial screening test for SLE due to its high sensitivity, it lacks specificity. ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, thus it is not as specific as anti-dsDNA antibodies for diagnosing SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

 

  • The provided picture displays the typical appearance of a slapped cheek  due to cutaneous vasodilatation, indicating a probable case of erythema infectiosum.
  • This condition is caused by the Parvovirus B19.
  • Parvovirus B19 is linked to pure red cell aplasia.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingivostomatitisis can be caused by Herpes virus.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum is an infection caused by a poxvirus 

 

Option D. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following MRI scan:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain, where the red arrow points to the Cerebellum. This part of the brain is known for its role in motor control, and it can also be involved in some cognitive functions like attention and language.

 

Key features visible in the MRI that help identify the Cerebellum include its characteristic lobulated structure located at the posterior base of the brain, just below the cerebrum and behind the brainstem and fourth ventricle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: Part of the brainstem, located higher and anteriorly relative to the cerebellum on sagittal images.

 

Option C. Brainstem: The brainstem, which includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla, is located anteriorly to the cerebellum in the image.

 

Option D. Cerebrum: The largest part of the brain, covering most of the upper sections of the image, involved in various higher-order functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cerebellum, distinct in its appearance and location in the posterior aspect of the brain, plays crucial roles in the coordination of voluntary movements and motor functions, which can be clearly seen on sagittal MRI scans.

choices.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.
High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.
It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.
Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in rapid sequence intubation? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.


Incorrect statement. Rapid sequence intubation typically involves administering an induction agent and a neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate endotracheal intubation without the risk of aspiration. However, in cardiac arrest patients, the priority is to secure the airway quickly without delay. Often, these patients do not require medications for intubation as they are unresponsive and without protective reflexes. Also, chest compressions and defibrillation (if indicated) are of higher priority.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done:
Correct statement. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen before RSI helps to denitrogenate the lungs, ensuring that the patient has an adequate oxygen reserve during the apneic period (the time between paralysis and successful intubation). The goal is to delay the onset of hypoxemia during the apnea.

 

Option B. High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used:
Correct statement. A high-volume low-pressure cuff on the endotracheal tube distributes the pressure over a larger area of the tracheal mucosa. This minimizes the risk of tracheal injury or necrosis.

 

Option D. Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously:
Correct statement. In RSI, immediately after administering the induction agent (to render the patient unconscious), a neuromuscular blocking agent (muscle relaxant) is given to paralyze the patient, thus facilitating endotracheal intubation. This rapid administration of drugs is to minimize the time between loss of protective reflexes and securing the airway, hence reducing the risk of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Rapid sequence intubation is not the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients due to the need for immediate airway management and ongoing chest compressions, making drug administration less critical.

choices.text: MRI to rule out enlarged heart

questions.text: The parents notice that their child is tired and that he has shortness of breath on climbing stairs and while lying down. What is the first investigation that you would do? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest x-ray

 

The first investigation to be done for a child who feels shortness of breath on climbing stairs and in the supine position is a chest x-ray.

 

The child having shortness of breath on dyspnea on exertion worsened in the supine position is orthopnea could be suggestive of congestive heart failure.

 

Causes -

 

  1. Respiratory causes include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD), pneumonia, and pulmonary embolism.
  2. Cardiovascular causes include congestive heart failure (CH), pulmonary edema, valvular heart defect, and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Evaluation

 

  • Oxygen saturation at rest and during physical activity
  • Chest x-ray is the first diagnostic test as pulmonary pathology or pulmonary edema and signs of CHF may be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: An echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac cause if the chest X-ray is abnormal

 

Option C: Spirometry to assess lung function when the chest x-ray is normal.

 

Option D: Cardiac MRI (Magnetic resonance imaging) is an emerging modality done to look for cardiomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a child presenting with shortness of breath on exertion and orthopnea, the first investigation should be a chest x-ray to evaluate potential pulmonary pathology and signs of congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A patient reports a painless mass that has been gradually increasing in size. An X-ray has been performed. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteochondroma

 

  • The X-ray image shows a typical presentation of an osteochondroma.
  • This is the most common benign bone tumor, often occurring in children and adolescents. It appears as a bony protrusion capped with cartilage, typically seen on long bones such as the femur, tibia, or humerus. In this X-ray, the characteristic projection from the bone with a cartilaginous cap suggests osteochondroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Myeloma: It typically presents with multiple, small "punched-out" lytic lesions across the skeletal system, not as a single protruding mass.

 

Option C. Ewing's Sarcoma: X-ray findings might show a layered "onion skin" appearance due to periosteal reaction, not a single mass like osteochondroma.

 

Option D. Osteosarcoma: X-rays usually show a mixture of bone destruction and new bone formation, often with a "sunburst" appearance.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Osteochondroma is a benign condition that typically presents as a painless, slowly growing mass near the growth plates of long bones. It's identified on X-rays by its distinct protrusion with a cartilaginous cap.

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) OCD

 

The Mental Health Gap Action Program (mhGAP) by the World Health Organization (WHO) is designed to scale up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The program focuses on priority conditions that are of high burden and can be managed effectively in primary care settings.

 

The mnemonic "MESSI DAD" can be used to remember the disorders included in the mhGAP program:

 

  • M: Mental disorders in children (Option A)
  • E: Epilepsy
  • S: Suicide
  • S: Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders (Option B)
  • I: Illicit drug use disorders
  • D: Depression (Option D)
  • A: Alcohol-related disorders
  • D: Dementia

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not included in the list of target conditions under the mhGAP program, which is why it is the correct answer to this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

 

The most likely causative organism based on the history and image given is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

 

T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. It is diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. Histopathological examination reveals yeast-like organisms with central septation.

 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

 

Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces are thermally dimorphic fungi and cause blastomycosis. Primary infection usually affects the lungs, which can later disseminate through the blood to form multiple abscesses at sites such as skin and bone. Culture at 25-30 degrees Celsius promotes hyphal growth. Microscopic examination of stained specimens shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

 

Option C. Aspergillus colonies have a velvety powdery surface, of which the color varies according to the species. Aspergillus fumigatus is seen as dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black colored. Yellow-green growth is seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. On microscopy, dichotomous branching at acute angles seen after staining is characteristic. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.

 

The image below shows Aspergillus niger colonies.

 

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured. On being stained by methenamine silver, the cyst wall appears black under the microscope. Trophozoites can also be seen after staining. Clinical features include dyspnea, fever, and cough. It can cause lethal pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. Diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates can be seen on chest radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with headache and seizures. On examination his BP is 220/110 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV Labetalol

 

In this case, the patient is experiencing a neurological hypertensive emergency, as indicated by his headache and seizures alongside a high blood pressure reading of 220/110 mm Hg. This condition could stem from several serious issues, including ischemic stroke, intracranial hemorrhage, or hypertensive encephalopathy.

 

The primary objective in managing a neurological hypertensive emergency is to safely reduce the blood pressure. For such emergencies, the first-line treatments typically include IV Nicardipine or IV Labetalol. Given that IV nicardipine is often not available in many Indian hospitals, IV labetalol becomes the preferred option, making it the Ans. in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Nitroglycerin: Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, are generally avoided in neurological emergencies because they cause vasodilation, which can increase cerebral blood flow. This increase in blood flow can elevate intracranial pressure, potentially worsening the patient's condition.

 

Option C. Oral Nifedipine: Oral medications are not suitable for emergency situations due to their delayed onset of action. Immediate reduction of blood pressure is crucial in this case, making oral nifedipine inappropriate.

 

Option D. IV Hydralazine: Although IV hydralazine is an arterial vasodilator, it is not recommended for neurological hypertensive emergencies. Similar to nitrates, it can lead to an increase in intracranial pressure and potentially exacerbate the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neurological hypertensive emergencies, the first-line treatment options for reducing blood pressure are IV nicardipine or IV labetalol, with IV labetalol being preferred if IV nicardipine is unavailable.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with fever, confusion, and altered mental status. On examination, he has jaundice, reduced urine output, low BP, and a feeble pulse. Lab studies reveal severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Peripheral smear revealed P. falciparum. What is the best treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV artesunate

 

The patient presents with severe falciparum malaria, indicated by symptoms such as fever, confusion, jaundice, reduced urine output, low blood pressure, and laboratory findings including severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Plasmodium falciparum is confirmed on a peripheral smear. Severe falciparum malaria is a medical emergency that requires prompt and effective treatment.

 

Key treatment guidelines: IV artesunate is the first-line treatment for severe malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum in non-pregnant adults. It acts rapidly and is effective in reducing parasitemia and improving clinical outcomes.

 

Once the patient's condition stabilizes and improves, the therapy is typically completed with an artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).

 

If IV artesunate is unavailable, then the alternative treatment is IV Quinine. After this, once the patient shows improvement, the treatment should be followed up with oral quinine combined with either doxycycline or clindamycin to complete the therapy. This approach ensures a comprehensive treatment regimen for severe malaria, with IV artesunate being the most recommended initial treatment due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine: This drug is not effective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance.

 

Option B. Artemesinin combination therapy (ACT): While ACT is used to complete the treatment after initial stabilization with IV artesunate, it is not the first-line treatment in severe cases.

 

Option D. Primaquine: This drug is used to eliminate the hypnozoite stages of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale and is not the primary treatment for severe falciparum malaria. Although a single dose of primaquine is sometimes given to reduce transmission, it is not the mainstay of therapy in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe falciparum malaria, the first-line treatment is IV artesunate, followed by artemisinin combination therapy (ACT) once the patient stabilizes.

questions.text: Tracheal innermost layer has which epithelial lining? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified columnar epithelium

 

The trachea, or windpipe, is lined with a specific type of epithelium designed to protect and facilitate the movement of mucus. The innermost layer of the trachea consists of pseudostratified columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to have multiple layers (strata) because the cells' nuclei are at different levels, giving a false impression of stratification (hence "pseudo"). However, it is actually a single layer of cells.

 

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium primarily consists of tall, column-like cells that are closely packed together. Despite appearing layered due to the varying positions of the nuclei, it is a single layer of cells. This structure is crucial for the trachea as it often contains cilia (tiny hair-like projections) and goblet cells that produce mucus. The cilia help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, aiding in keeping the airways clear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of flat, thin cells and is usually found in areas where rapid diffusion or filtration is required, such as the alveoli in the lungs. It is not suitable for the trachea, which needs a more robust lining to handle mucus and cilia.

 

Option B. Ciliary epithelium: While the pseudostratified columnar epithelium in the trachea does contain ciliated cells, "ciliary epithelium" itself is not a distinct classification of epithelial tissue. Therefore, this option is incorrect as a type of epithelial lining.

 

Option D. Cuboidal epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of cube-shaped cells and is generally found in glandular tissues or ducts (like kidney tubules). It is not found lining the trachea, as it lacks the specialized structure needed for mucus movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The innermost layer of the trachea is lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which appears layered due to the positioning of cell nuclei but is actually a single layer of cells designed to protect the respiratory tract and facilitate mucus movement.

questions.text: A patient with suicidal tendency ingested some substance. He presents with tachycardia, dilated pupil, and hypertension. Identify the drug. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

The patient's symptoms—tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension—are indicative of a sympathomimetic toxidrome, which is most commonly caused by stimulants like cocaine. Cocaine is a potent sympathomimetic agent that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to increased heart rate (tachycardia), elevated blood pressure (hypertension), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These clinical signs are classic for cocaine toxicity, especially in a setting involving substance use with suicidal intent.

 

Cocaine blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, leading to an excess of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, which accounts for the heightened sympathetic activity observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), bradycardia, and respiratory depression. It does not fit the clinical presentation of dilated pupils, tachycardia, and hypertension, which are opposite of opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine, like heroin, is an opioid that causes pupil constriction (miosis) rather than dilation. It also leads to decreased heart rate and blood pressure, contrasting the symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Chlorpheniramine: Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties that can cause pupil dilation and mild tachycardia, but it is less likely to cause significant hypertension. Furthermore, chlorpheniramine is not commonly associated with substance abuse for suicidal intent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine toxicity is characterized by sympathetic overdrive symptoms such as tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension, making it the likely substance in cases of suspected sympathomimetic drug overdose.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein’s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text:
A woman presented with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. NSAIDs can improve the symptoms and have disease modifying activity.
  2. Absence of erosion rules out the diagnosis.
  3. It is associated with raised ESR and CRP.
  4. HLA DR4 is related to the prognosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) III, IV are correct

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis
      • Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
         
  • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
    • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Usually DIP is not involved in and is not used for diagnosis but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
    • Lumbar Spine is usually spared.
       
  • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
  • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers
       
  • Treatment:
    • Exercises to maintain muscle strength and joint mobility.
    • NSAIDs
    • Glucocorticoid therapy esp. in vasculitis.
    • Immunosuppressive therapy by leflunomide, DMARDs, methotrexate (drug of choice), anticytokine, etanercept, cyclosporine, infliximab, adalimumab, abatacept.

 

Other Options:

 

  • NSAIDs are anti-inflammatory drugs and not disease-modifying drugs. NSAIDs are used for symptomatic treatment in RA. They have few side effects but also have potential adverse effects like GI bleeding.
  • Bone erosion is a central feature of rheumatoid arthritis and is associated with disease severity and poor functional outcome. Erosion of periarticular cortical bone, the typical feature observed on plain radiographs in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, results from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.

questions.text: Glucose load for screening diabetes in pregnancy is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 75 gm

 

Explanation:

 

According to the majority of guidelines, including the WHO, IADPSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups), and DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India) guidelines, a 75 gm glucose load is used for screening diabetes in pregnancy.

 

Note - The ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists) guidelines follow a two-step process where the first step involves a 50 gm glucose load for screening, and if positive, a 100 gm glucose load for confirmation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25 gm: Not used in any standard screening protocol.

 

Option B. 50 gm: Used in the initial step of the ACOG two-step screening process, but not the most common single-step screening load.

 

Option D. 100 gm: Used in the second step of the ACOG two-step screening process, not for initial screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For screening diabetes in pregnancy, the 75 gm glucose load is widely used according to various international guidelines, including WHO and IADPSG.

questions.text: All the following are indications of caesarean section except? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Previous history of macrosomia

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options B, C and D are Absolute Indications for caesarean section. It means vaginal delivery is not possible

 

Absolute indications for caesarean section include:

 

  • Central placenta praevia
  • Contracted pelvis or CPD
  • Pelvic mass causing obstruction
  • Advanced CA cervix
  • Vaginal obstruction (atresia, stenosis)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous history of macrosomia is not an indication for caesarean section.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics page 670

choices.text: Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and aerobic during night time
Anaerobic during day time and night time
Aerobic during day time and night time

questions.text: A civil engineer in Kerala is designing a wastewater treatment facility for a growing town. He considers implementing an oxidation pond, a natural wastewater treatment system. Which of the following best describes the microbial activity of the oxidation pond? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aerobic during day time and anaerobic during night time.

 

  • Oxidation ponds uses aerobic method during day time and anaerobic during night time.
  • Oxidation pond also known as - waste stabilization pond/redox pond/sewage lagoons
  • Oxidation ponds or sewage lagoons are a popular method of purifying sewage for small communities. 
  • These are open shallow pools of around 1-1.5 m depth with an inlet and outlet. 
  • The oxidation ponds have algae, types of saprophytic bacteria and sunlight-which helps in aerobic sewage treatment during day time and anaerobic treatment of sewage during night time. 
  • The effluent can be used for land irrigation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxidation ponds utilize aerobic microbial activity during the day and anaerobic activity at night to treat wastewater effectively.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with chest pain and an ECG was taken. What will be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior MI

 

The ECG shows ST elevations primarily in leads V1, V2, V3, and V4. These elevations are also seen to some extent in V5 and aVL, with reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF. These findings are characteristic of an anterior myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior MI: This would present with ST elevations in leads II, III, and aVF. These changes are not observed in the provided ECG.

 

Option C. Lateral MI: This type of MI would show ST elevations primarily in leads I, aVL, and possibly V5 and V6, but not in leads V1 to V4.

 

Option D. Posterior MI: The diagnosis of a posterior MI is typically confirmed by obtaining posterior leads (V7, V8, and V9) to demonstrate ST elevations. Alternatively, it can be inferred from characteristic ST depressions in leads V1 and V2, often with a tall R wave and upright T wave, which are not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior MI is characterized by ST elevations in leads V1 to V4, with possible involvement of V5 and AVL, and reciprocal ST depressions in leads II, III, and aVF.

questions.text:
Many GPCR receptors act via increase in cAMP. There are several steps involved in this mechanism as given below. Which of the following is correct sequence of events in cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET May 2024)

 

Steps involved


1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
2. Activation of PKA
3. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
4. Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

 

The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway is:

 

  1. Activation of adenylate cyclase
  2. Conversion of ATP to cAMP
  3. Activation of PKA
  4. Phosphorylation of target proteins

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: B. 1, 3, 2 and 4

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) weakness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyper-reflexia

 

Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) lesions are associated with a specific set of clinical features due to the disruption of the central motor pathways that originate in the cerebral cortex and descend through the brainstem and spinal cord to synapse on the lower motor neurons. The key features of UMN lesions include:

 

  • Hyper-reflexia: This is characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. The loss of inhibitory modulation from the cortex leads to an overactive reflex arc.
  • Spasticity: Increased muscle tone that is velocity-dependent, often seen in conjunction with hyper-reflexia.
  • Babinski sign: An abnormal reflex where the big toe extends upward when the sole of the foot is stimulated.
  • No significant muscle atrophy: While mild disuse atrophy can occur over time, it is not as pronounced as in lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions.
  • No fasciculations: Fasciculations, or spontaneous contractions of muscle fibers, are indicative of LMN lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrophy: Significant muscle atrophy is a hallmark of LMN lesions due to denervation of the muscles. It is not typically seen in UMN lesions except for mild disuse atrophy.

 

Option C. Rigidity: Rigidity is associated with extrapyramidal disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, and is characterized by increased muscle tone that is uniform and not velocity-dependent.

 

Option D. Fasciculations: Fasciculations are indicative of LMN lesions and result from spontaneous depolarization of lower motor neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) weakness is hyper-reflexia, characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. This occurs due to the loss of inhibitory control from the brain on the reflex arcs in the spinal cord.

questions.text: The vasodilator Nitric oxide is synthesized by which amino acid? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L -Arginine

 

Explanation

 

Nitric oxide is synthesized from the amino acid L-arginine. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). L-arginine is converted to L-citrulline with the release of NO. This process is crucial for the regulation of vascular tone, as NO is a potent vasodilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  L-Citrulline: While L-citrulline is involved in the nitric oxide cycle, it is not the precursor for NO synthesis. Instead, it is a byproduct of NO synthesis from L-arginine. L-citrulline can be recycled back to L-arginine, which can then be used again for NO synthesis.

 

Option C.  Glycine: Glycine is a simple amino acid involved in various metabolic pathways, but it is not the precursor for nitric oxide synthesis. Glycine plays roles in the synthesis of proteins, purines, and other molecules, but not directly in the production of NO.

 

Option D.  Lysine: Lysine, an essential amino acid, is not involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide. It plays roles in protein synthesis and other metabolic processes, but NO synthesis specifically requires L-arginine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

choices.text: 1-d, 2- c, 3- b, 4-a
1-c, 2- a, 3- d, 4- b
1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d

questions.text: Match the following stains with their respective tissue: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-b, 3-d, 4-c

 

The correct match is 1- a, 2- b, 3- d, 4-c.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Prussian blue (a): This stain is used to detect iron in tissue samples, specifically hemosiderin, a storage form of iron.
  • PAS (b): The Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used to highlight glycogen and other carbohydrates in tissues. It is commonly used in diagnosing certain storage diseases and fungal infections.
  • Congo red (c): Congo red is a special stain used to detect amyloid, a protein that can abnormally accumulate in tissues, leading to conditions such as amyloidosis. Under polarized light, amyloid stained with Congo red shows apple-green birefringence.
  • Fite Faraco stain (d): This stain is used to detect leprosy bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae) in tissue samples. It is a modification of the acid-fast stain and is specifically tailored to highlight these bacteria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies

 

Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once symptoms appear. It affects the central nervous system. It is a zoonotic disease, transmitted by a deep bite or scratch from an animal with rabies, which is, in 99% of the cases, a dog. It is preventable by a vaccine.

 

Nipah virus infection is fatal in 40 to 70 percent of cases.

 

Ebola case fatality rates have varied from 25% to 90% in past outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus infection has a fatality rate of 40% to 70%. While severe, it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies once symptoms develop.

 

Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus disease has variable case fatality rates, ranging from 25% to 90% in different outbreaks. However, it is not as consistently fatal as rabies once symptoms manifest.

 

Option D. Zika: Zika virus infection is typically mild, and while it can cause severe complications such as microcephaly in newborns if contracted during pregnancy, it does not have a high mortality rate in symptomatic individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies has the highest mortality rate once clinical symptoms appear, making it virtually 100% fatal without immediate post-exposure prophylaxis.

choices.text: Stop tobacco and don’t worry about the patch
Chemical cauterization with trichloroacetic acetic acid

questions.text: A chronic tobacco chewer presents with left cheek swelling. On examination a white membrane is seen over the gingiva buccal fold, which doesn’t get rubbed off. What will be your next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical excision and biopsy

 

The patient is likely suffering from leukoplakia in the buccal mucosa. In such cases, a biopsy is crucial to rule out malignancy. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, so direct excision and biopsy are the most appropriate first steps to determine the nature of the lesion and guide further management.

 

Surgical Excision and Biopsy:

 

  • This is the preferred step when dealing with potential premalignant or malignant lesions like leukoplakia. It helps to both treat the lesion (by removing it) and diagnose its exact nature (via the biopsy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop Tobacco and Don’t Worry About the Patch: While quitting tobacco is always beneficial, merely stopping without addressing the lesion can be risky. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, and leaving it untreated without proper diagnosis could lead to missed early cancer detection.

 

Option C. Chemical Cauterization with Trichloroacetic Acid: Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is an agent used for chemical cauterization. It has been used for benign lesions, warts, and certain other conditions, but it’s not the primary method of treatment for suspicious lesions like leukoplakia. Proper histopathological diagnosis is essential before considering treatment options.

 

Option D. MVAC Chemotherapy: MVAC is a chemotherapy regimen that includes Methotrexate, Vinblastine, Doxorubicin (Adriamycin), and Cisplatin. This regimen is typically used for treating advanced bladder cancer. It’s not a frontline treatment for an undiagnosed white patch in the oral cavity like leukoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukoplakia can potentially transform into a malignancy, and thus, any suspicious lesion in the oral cavity should be excised and biopsied for a definitive diagnosis and to rule out cancer.

questions.text: A known patient of tuberculosis, on INH for the past 3 months complains of numbness, tingling and burning sensation in all the extremities. What could be vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

This is the correct answer. Isoniazid (INH) can lead to a deficiency in Vitamin B6. Peripheral neuropathy, which includes symptoms like numbness, tingling, and burning sensations in the extremities, is a common side effect of Vitamin B6 deficiency. Therefore, the patient's symptoms are likely a result of this deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) Deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause neuropathy and neurological symptoms, but it's less likely to be associated with INH use specifically. However, it's essential to consider Vitamin B12 levels in tuberculosis patients, as they may have dietary restrictions or other factors that could lead to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Deficiency: Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause a condition called beriberi, which can include neurological symptoms. However, INH is not known to directly cause Vitamin B1 deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin) Deficiency: Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes skin issues and neurological symptoms. INH can indirectly affect niacin levels, but it's not a common cause of niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase which is required for synthesis of biologically active form of pyridoxine (B6) i.e. pyridoxal phosphate. Thus, isoniazid inhibits the formation of the active form of B6.
  • As Vit. B6 (PLP) is required for niacin (B3) synthesis from tryptophan, hence isoniazid therapy also causes Niacin deficiency.
  • In this question, best answer to mark is B6 as INH directly inhibits B6 formation.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-371

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.

questions.text: A woman who got IUCD inserted at a PHC, now presents with bleeding. What should be done by the MO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron supplement and observation

 

Bleeding after IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is a common and typically normal physiological response. It is generally expected to subside within the first two menstrual cycles. While reassurance is important, simply reassuring the patient may not be sufficient, as persistent bleeding can lead to anemia.

 

The best approach is to supplement with iron (e.g., ferrous sulfate 200 mg TDS for 8 weeks) to prevent anemia while observing the patient. If the bleeding does not subside despite supplementation, the IUCD may need to be removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance: While reassurance is important, it alone may not be enough if the bleeding persists and leads to anemia.

 

Option B. Remove IUCD: Immediate removal of the IUCD is not the first line of management unless the bleeding persists despite supplementation and observation.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and IV fluids: These are not indicated unless there is an infection or severe bleeding, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron supplementation and observation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and skinny appearance. Which of the following condition best fit the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marasmus

 

Marasmus is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by energy deficiency. A child with marasmus typically has a very thin, wasted appearance due to the loss of muscle mass and subcutaneous fat. This condition results from inadequate intake of calories and protein over a prolonged period. In the context of the question, the 4-year-old child with muscle wasting and a skinny appearance aligns with the clinical presentation of marasmus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kwashiorkor: (Fatty baby/ anasarca) This condition is also a form of severe malnutrition but is primarily due to protein deficiency rather than a total calorie deficiency. Children with kwashiorkor often appear with edema, an enlarged liver, and a swollen abdomen. They may have a more plump appearance due to fluid retention, not a skinny one.

 

Option C. Stunting: This term refers to chronic malnutrition that results in reduced growth rate and height for a child's age. While stunted growth is a sign of malnutrition, it does not specifically account for the muscle wasting and extreme thinness described in the question.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as marasmus directly fits the description provided in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marasmus is characterized by severe wasting of muscle and subcutaneous fat, leading to a very thin, emaciated appearance in affected children.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produce urease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Helicobacter pylori

 

Helicobacter pylori is well-known for its ability to produce urease, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of urea into carbon dioxide and ammonia. This enzymatic activity is crucial for the survival of H. pylori in the acidic environment of the stomach. By producing ammonia, H. pylori can neutralize the acidity around it, creating a more hospitable environment for itself and contributing to its pathogenicity, which is associated with gastric ulcers and chronic gastritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella does not produce urease and is known for causing foodborne illnesses primarily affecting the intestinal tract.

 

Option C. Escherichia coli: Incorrect, while some strains of E. coli can produce urease, it is not a characteristic feature, and they are primarily known for other virulence factors.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella does not produce urease and is known for causing dysentery or shigellosis through invasion and inflammation of the intestinal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urease-producing organisms: (Mnemonic-PUNCH)

 

  • Proteus
  • asma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum
  •  H. pylori

questions.text: A child presented in the pediatric OPD with fever for past 5 days along with cough, coryza, conjunctivitis. The mother also complained of a non itchy rash that appeared just a day back starting from behind the ears involving the face and spreading to the trunk also involving palms and soles. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles


The clinical presentation described is characteristic of measles, a viral infection caused by the measles virus. Measles typically presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza (runny nose), and conjunctivitis, often referred to as the "3 C's" of measles. These symptoms are followed by the appearance of a maculopapular rash that typically starts behind the ears, spreads to the face, and then to the rest of the body, including the trunk, palms, and soles.

 

The hallmark features of measles include the "3 C's" (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and a characteristic rash that spreads from the head downward to the rest of the body. This description fits the scenario provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Rubella, also known as German measles, presents with a milder illness compared to measles. The rash in rubella usually starts on the face and spreads to the body but is typically accompanied by mild fever and swollen lymph nodes, especially behind the ears. The rash in rubella is often itchy, which contrasts with the non-itchy rash described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Dengue: Dengue fever presents with symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, rash, and bleeding tendencies. Thrombocytopenia and other signs of bleeding are common in dengue, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is not applicable as the clinical features align with a diagnosis of measles.

 

Educational Objective:


Measles is characterized by the "3 C's" (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis) and a non-itchy rash that spreads from behind the ears to the rest of the body, including the palms and soles.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the hybrid muscle partially spared in a patient who presented with sciatica and tender hamstrings? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obturator nerve

 

The adductor magnus is a hybrid muscle in the medial compartment of the thigh, which is partially spared in cases of sciatica due to its dual nerve supply. The adductor magnus has two heads: the ischial head (hamstring part) and the pubic head (adductor part). The adductor part is supplied by the obturator nerve, while the hamstring part is supplied by the tibial component of the sciatic nerve. In patients with sciatica, the obturator nerve can still supply the adductor part of the adductor magnus, leading to partial sparing of muscle function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common peroneal nerve: This nerve supplies muscles in the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg and does not innervate the adductor magnus or any muscles in the medial thigh.

 

Option B. Femoral nerve: This nerve primarily supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh, including muscles like the quadriceps femoris, and does not innervate the adductor magnus.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: Although the tibial nerve supplies the hamstring part of the adductor magnus, it is affected in sciatica, leading to the involvement of muscles it innervates, unlike the obturator nerve which partially spares the muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quick revision of the hybrid muscles of the upper and lower limbs:

choices.text: Hepatitis B virus

questions.text: Donor blood should be screened for the following infections except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dengue virus

 

Dengue virus is not typically included in the mandatory screening process for blood donations. While dengue is a significant public health issue, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions, its transmission through blood transfusion is rare and not considered a primary risk compared to the other pathogens listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis C virus: This virus is a common cause of liver disease and is a bloodborne pathogen. Blood donations are routinely screened for HCV to prevent transmission through transfusion.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus: HIV is a critical pathogen to screen for in donated blood because it can be transmitted through blood transfusion and is responsible for causing AIDS.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B virus: Like HCV, HBV is a major bloodborne pathogen that can lead to serious liver disease. Blood is routinely screened for HBV to ensure it is safe for transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Donor blood require screening for infectious disease pathogen:

 

  • Hepatitis C virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  • Hepatitis B virus
  • Malaria 
  • Syphilis.

questions.text: A 20-year old male patient is presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis. On further testing Anti glomerular basement membrane antibody is positive, what will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Goodpasture syndrome

 

  • Given clinical scenario is suggestive of good pasture syndrome as patient is presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis along with Anti glomerular basement membrane antibody.
  • It is type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • It belongs to type 1 RPGN
  • The autoantibodies are directed against the alpha 3 chain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group. This immunofluorescence pattern shows positivity with antibody to IgG and has a smooth, diffuse, linear pattern that is characteristic for deposition of glomerular basement membrane antibody with Goodpasture syndrome. Serologic testing for anti-GBM in patient serum is often positive.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glomerular nephropathy: This is a general term for diseases affecting the glomeruli, but it does not specifically fit the provided clinical scenario.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis: While Goodpasture syndrome is a type of glomerulonephritis, the specific presence of anti-GBM antibodies and the combination of hematuria and hemoptysis point directly to Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. Alport’s syndrome: This is a genetic disorder characterized by glomerulonephritis, end-stage kidney disease, and hearing loss, and it does not typically present with anti-GBM antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies, hematuria, and hemoptysis, and is a type II hypersensitivity reaction associated with type I Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given clinical picture and the barrel-shaped eggs are suggestive of infection with Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

Other Options


Option A. Giardia lamblia: The stool examination usually reveals oval-shaped cysts or trophozoites. Giardia does not produce eggs, distinguishing it from helminthic infections.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: The eggs are typically oval-shaped and brown-colored. They have a distinct thick shell and are not barrel-shaped, which helps differentiate them from Trichuris trichiura eggs.

 

 

Option D. Ancylostoma duodenale:  The eggs are oval and thin-shelled, significantly different in appearance from the barrel-shaped eggs of Trichuris trichiura.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Table listing appearance of various organism in stool/sputum examination

questions.text: The sensory area marked in the image is primarily innervated by which nerve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radial nerve 

 

The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

 

 

  • Origin: Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Primarily a motor nerve for the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm. It also has sensory branches for the skin on the back of the hand and the posterior arm and forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis, and all the extensor muscles in the forearm.
  • Sensory Innervation: Supplies the posterior surface of the arm and forearm, and the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN):

 

  • Origin: It's a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Main Functions: Purely motor nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: All the deep extensors of the forearm, including extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis, and others.
  • Sensory Innervation: The PIN does not have a sensory function.

 

Option C. Median Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the medial and lateral roots from the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor muscles in the anterior forearm (except flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus) and thenar muscles and first two lumbricals in the hand.
  • Sensory Innervation: Palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers and the associated palm area.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies muscles in the hand and a few in the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus in the forearm. In the hand, it supplies most intrinsic muscles, including the hypothenar muscles, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • Sensory Innervation: Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial one and a half fingers and the associated hand region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory function of the radial nerve is provided by its four main sensory branches:

 

  • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies the lateral aspect of the anterior upper arm between the deltoid and the elbow.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies part of the posterior aspect of the upper arm.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: Supplies a tapered strip of the middle portion of the posterior forearm.
  • Superficial branch of the radial nerve: Supplies the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and the associated areas of the palm.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia, who did not respond to haloperidol and thioridazine, was started on drug A. After beginning treatment with drug A, the patient's psychotic symptoms improved; however, he developed sialorrhea, dyslipidemia, weight gain, and hyperglycemia. Which drug is most likely to be 'drug A'? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clozapine

 

The description of the patient's response and side effects suggests that 'drug A' is most likely Clozapine. Clozapine is known for its effectiveness in treatment-resistant schizophrenia, where other antipsychotics like haloperidol and thioridazine have failed. It is distinguished by its side effect profile, which includes sialorrhea (excessive salivation), significant weight gain, dyslipidemia (abnormal lipid levels), and hyperglycemia (high blood sugar). These side effects are more pronounced with Clozapine compared to other antipsychotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ziprasidone: While it is an atypical antipsychotic, Ziprasidone is less likely to cause significant weight gain and metabolic side effects compared to Clozapine.

 

Option C. Risperidone: Risperidone can cause weight gain and metabolic side effects, but it is less likely to cause sialorrhea and is not as commonly used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia as Clozapine.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: Aripiprazole is known for having a more favorable metabolic side effect profile and is less likely to cause significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia compared to Clozapine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the treatment of treatment-resistant schizophrenia, Clozapine is often effective where other antipsychotics have failed. However, its use is associated with notable side effects including sialorrhea, significant weight gain, dyslipidemia, and hyperglycemia.

 

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 222-224.

questions.text: What is the cause of the lesion shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lightning strike

 

The image shows fern-like patterns, known as Lichtenberg flowers or filigree burns, which are characteristic of lightening injury.

 

Filigree burns:

 

  • Also called Arborescent or Lichtenberger’s flowers
  • They pathognomonic feature of lightening
  • Superficial, thin, irregular and tortuous markings on skin like branches of tree (fern like pattern).
  • They are caused by Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells (from superficial capillaries) along the path of electric current. Hence, they indicate the path taken by the discharge.
  • They do not follow the path of major blood vessels, but only follow the superficial capillaries
  • Though called Filigree Burns but they are not actually burns
  • They are transient erythema which appears within a few minutes to 1 hour of accident and gradually fades within 24 – 48 hours if the person survives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electrocution: Electrocution typically causes electrical burns which are different from the filigree burns seen in lightning strikes. These burns are usually deep and may show entry and exit wounds.

 

Option C. Marbling: Marbling refers to a postmortem change where blood vessels become visible as greenish-black streaks on the skin, occurring due to decomposition and is not related to electrical injuries.

 

Option D. Trickling down of acid: Acid injuries typically cause chemical burns with distinct, often more severe damage to the skin and tissues, and do not produce the characteristic fern-like patterns seen in lightning strikes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filigree burns or Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic for lightning strikes and appear as superficial, fern-like patterns on the skin that fade within 24-48 hours.

choices.text: Elective C-section has no role in reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury
In a patient being planned for induction of labor, night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld
In active labor, if RBS <70 mg%, D5 is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%
Capillary blood glucose monitoring levels are kept at fasting- 95 mg%; 1 h postprandial- 140 mg%; 2 h postprandial: 120 mg%

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding management of diabetes in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elective C-section has no role in reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury

 

Explanation:

 

  • False statement regarding management of diabetes in pregnancy is option A.
  • The Cesarean section is found to be protective against traumatic injuries such as brachial plexus injury, in macrosomic babies born to mothers with diabetes.
  • Elective LSCS is recommended when the estimated fetal weight is > 4.5kg in diabetic mothers to reduce the incidence of birth trauma

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In a patient being planned for induction of labor, night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld: In a planned delivery, although the bedtime dose of intermediate-acting insulin is given, it is recommended that the morning dose must be withheld

 

Insulin Management for Labor Induction or Scheduled Cesarean Delivery

 

 

Option C. In active labor, if RBS <70 mg%, D5 is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%: In active labor, if RBS (Random blood glucose) <70 mg%, D5 (5% dextrose) is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%. Before initiation of labor, normal saline is used for iv infusion.

 

Option D. Capillary blood glucose monitoring levels are kept at fasting- 95 mg%; 1 h postprandial- 140 mg%; 2 h postprandial: 120 mg%: Self-monitoring of capillary blood glucose is advised in a pregnant woman diagnosed with diabetes. The glucose goals recommended are:

 

  • Fasting: 95 mg/dL
  • 1 h postprandial: 140 mg/dL
  • 2 h postprandial: 120 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elective C-section can reduce the incidence of brachial plexus injury in pregnancies complicated by diabetes, especially in cases of fetal macrosomia.

 

Ref: Page no 2807, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
